title-group.article-title: Heterogeneity of Trade Patterns in High-Tech Goods Across Established and Emerging Exporters: A Panel Data Analysis

abstract.p: This study aims to identify underlying fundamental factors behind high-tech exports by the established and emerging countries, separately. The author also examines whether the two export patterns converge over time. Based on the gravity approach, a generalized method of moments panel estimator is applied to rigorously address the endogeneity problem in both static and dynamic versions of the model. In addition, the nonstationary and cointegrating features of variables are discussed. The author finds that high-tech exports from the emerging countries are mainly based on foreign direct investment inflows and participation in the international production chain, as well as a high degree of export concentration, while high-tech exports from the established exporters are mainly linked to industrial infrastructures, research and development, and export diversification. Nevertheless, the two export patterns converge over time.

ref.mixed-citation: The most popular criterion to define high-tech goods is the share of research and devel- opment expenditure relative to the industry's total sale and the ratio of skilled labor to the total labor force in the industry. Based on the first, Eberth (2008) identified 252 product categories at the six-digit harmonized system level as high-tech goods. This study follows the same definition for these goods.

Linder (1961) interprets the inequality between two countries' per capita incomes as "taste" differences between them. In this case, a higher difference in per capita incomes leads to lower intraindustry trade between the two countries. On the contrary, the same variable is taken by Helpman and Krugman (1985) as a measure for the difference in the capital labor endowment ratio. According to them, higher per capita income differences induce international trade of the Heckscher-Ohlin type. As a result, a positive coefficient for DGDPP supports the Heckscher-Ohlin theorem while a negative one is instead in line with the Linder (1961) approach.

The exporting countries include nineteen established exporters (belonging to the group of developed countries) and eleven emerging exporters (belonging to the group of developing coun- tries) in the sector. The complete list is provided in the Appendix.

There are two versions of the dynamic ABB model: difference and system GMM. This study uses the difference version, which instrumentalizes the endogenous variables by differencing them and using the generalized method of moments (Verbeek 2004, pp. 353-366). In this approach, the instruments are chosen from inside the model, that is, the first-differenced variables are used as their own instruments.
Not reported for the sake of brevity, the results are also stable when replacing explanatory variables with a set of alternatives.
